{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} [[File:Protest against Faure Gnassingbe in Belgium.jpg|thumb|Protest against [[Faure Gnassingbé]] in [[Belgium]] in October 2017]] The '''2017–18 Togolese protests''' are a significant representation of civil unrest in [[Togo]] and [[Protests against Faure Gnassingbé|against the 50 year rule]] of the father-son combination of [[Gnassingbé Eyadéma]] and [[Faure Gnassingbé]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/togo-protests_us_59b05298e4b0354e440f0686 |title=Massive Protests Call For An End To Togo's 50-Year Political Dynasty |last=Reuters |date=6 September 2017 |work=Huffington Post |access-date=4 January 2018 |language=en-US}}</ref> The protesters demanded that the president honour the [[Togolese constitutional referendum, 1992|1992 constitution]], and demanding that he step down immediately. Gnassingbé offered the protesters the option of enacting the two-term limit set in the constitution effective from 2018,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/more-protests-planned-for-togo_us_5a307e5ce4b06a512dd69bae |title=More Protests Planned for Togo |last=Wong (Omowale) |first=Dwayne |date=13 December 2017 |work=HuffPost |language=en-US |access-date=4 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://nobelwomensinitiative.org/meet-farida-nabourema-togo/ |title=Meet Farida Nabourema, Togo |date=25 November 2017 |publisher=Nobel Women's Initiative |access-date=4 January 2018 |language=en-US}}</ref> thus ensuring that he could stay in power until 2030. This has been rejected by the opposition.<ref name=":0">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-41332072 |title=Boy of nine 'killed in Togo protests' |last=Smith |first=Alex Duval |date=21 September 2017 |work=BBC News |access-date=4 January 2018 |language=en-GB}}</ref> As the protests continued, the opposition started focusing more on protesting Gnassingbé's rule.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ritzen |first=Yarno |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/02/togo-government-opposition-hold-crisis-talks-180214215230816.html |title=Togo government and opposition to hold crisis talks |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=14 February 2018 |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref>
Starting in August 2017, the opposition has held protests on a near-weekly basis.<ref name=Vanguard/> The scale of the protests have been enormous, with some estimates claiming 800,000 present at one protest in a country of 6.6 million.<ref name=":0" /> The demonstrations are also taking place all over the country, even in the north, the traditional power base for the Gnassingbé family.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/04/world/africa/togo-protests-faure-gnassingbe.html |title=Togo Rallies for Change After 50 Years of Rule by One Family |last=Besliu |first=Raluca |date=4 November 2017 |work=The New York Times |access-date=4 January 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> The Togolese government has responded to these protests by shutting down the internet, or block various apps, such as [[WhatsApp]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/09/togo-blocks-internet-protests-continue-170908040118559.html |title=Togo blocks internet as protests continue |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=8 September 2017 |access-date=4 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/togo-protests/togo-blocks-internet-as-protesters-march-for-second-day-idUSL8N1LO4MZ |title=Togo blocks Internet as protesters march for second day |date=7 September 2017 |publisher=Reuters |access-date=4 January 2018}}</ref> The protesters have utilised social media, using the [[hashtag]] #togodebut for publicity.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://qz.com/1083741/togo-has-blocked-whatsapp-again-to-gag-anti-government-protests/ |title=WhatsApp's role as a government protest tool is in the spotlight again as Togo blocks it |last=Dahir |first=Abdi Latif |work=Quartz |access-date=4 January 2018 |language=en-US}}</ref> The protests and police response have resulted in the deaths of at least 16 people, including two soldiers.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.ug/embattled-togo-leader-breaks-silence-new-year-address/ |title=Embattled Togo leader breaks silence in New Year address |work=[[The Independent (Uganda)|The Independent Uganda]] |agency=AFP |date=5 January 2018 |accessdate=10 January 2018}}</ref> {{As of|August 2018}}, Gnassingbé has offered some concessions to the opposition, but has held onto power due to his crackdown on activists.<ref>{{cite news |title=A year after big protests, Faure Gnassingbé hangs on in Togo |url=https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2018/08/18/a-year-after-big-protests-faure-gnassingbe-hangs-on-in-togo |work=The Economist |accessdate=3 September 2018 |language=en |date=18 August 2018}}</ref>
==Background== {{Main|Protests against Faure Gnassingbé}}
==History== ===August 2017=== On 19 August, thousands of protesters took to the streets, mostly in the city of [[Sokodé]]. Some protesters chanted "50 years is too long".<ref name="Nabourema">{{cite news |last=Nabourema |first=Farida |url=http://africanarguments.org/2017/08/25/50-years-of-hurt-togo-protesters-vow-to-continue/ |title=50 years of hurt: Togo protesters vow to continue |work=African Arguments |date=25 August 2017 |accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> Protests also occurred in [[Lomé]], [[Bafilo]], [[Anié]], and [[Kara, Togo|Kara]].<ref name="Vox Daily">{{cite news |url=https://www.thedailyvox.co.za/togo-protests-broken/ |title=Togo protests: Why have they erupted? |work=The Daily Vox |date=21 August 2017 |accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> Security forces shot and killed two civilians while dispersing protesters. Other civilians burned security vehicles and killed seven security men.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kanyi |first1=A.B. Kafui |last2=Abodoli |first2=Dominic |url=http://www.ghananewsagency.org/politics/political-protest-in-togo-claims-nine-lives-121246 |title=Political protest in Togo claims nine lives |work=Ghana News Agency |agency=GNA |accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> Photographs of the violence spread on social media.<ref name="Nabourema"/> About 27 people were arrested, and 15 protesters identified as supporters of the Pan African National Party were given jail sentences of 5–9 months.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.pulse.com.gh/news/world/togo-15-anti-government-protesters-jailed-id7234663.html |title=15 anti-government protesters jailed |date=31 August 2017 |work=Pulse |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> Some of those arrested later said they were tortured at the headquarters of Togo's secret police, and placed in Lomé's central prison.<ref>{{cite news |last=O'Grady |first=Siobhan |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-togo-political-prisoners-torture-20180604-story.html |title='It's just barbarity': Togo's political prisoners describe torture in police custody |work=Los Angeles Times |date=4 June 2018 |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref>
Opposition parties called for a general strike to take place on 25 August, which slowed business and caused Lomé to enter a security lockdown. Togolese minister Gilbert Bawara criticized the strike, calling it "the campaign of terror, intimidation and threats".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-4824044/Togos-capital-tense-opposition-call-stay-home.html |title=Togo's capital tense after opposition call to stay home |work=Daily Mail |agency=AFP |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> Togolese Prime Minister [[Komi Sélom Klassou]] led a pro-government counter-protest in [[Lomé]] on 29 August.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.africanews.com/2017/08/30/pro-govt-counter-protest-staged-in-togo-the-morning-call/ |title=Pro-govt counter-protest staged in Togo [The Morning Call] |work=[[Africanews]] |date=30 August 2017 |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref> [[Ghana Immigration Service|Ghanaian immigration officers]] increased security of the Ghana–Togo border for Togolese fleeing to Ghana because of the unrest.<ref>{{cite news |last=Taylor |first=Mildred Europa |url=http://www.pulse.com.gh/news/local/togo-unrest-ghana-tightens-security-at-its-border-as-tension-in-togo-rises-id7207560.html |title=Ghana tightens security at its border as tension in Togo rises |work=Pulse |date=25 August 2017 |accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref>
===September 2017=== On 5 September, in an effort to disrupt planned protests, the Toglose government cut off the internet, blocked the use of [[WhatsApp]], and filtered international calls.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mtshali |first=Khanya |url=https://qz.com/1070753/togo-shuts-down-internet-to-counter-anti-faure-gnassingbe-protests/ |title=Togo has shut down the internet to counter anti-government protests |work=[[Quartz Africa]] |date=7 September 2017 |accessdate=10 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Koutonin |first=Mawuna |url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2017/sep/21/no-business-no-boozing-no-casual-sex-when-togo-turned-off-the-internet |title=No business, no boozing, no casual sex: when Togo turned off the internet |date=21 September 2017 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=23 December 2017}}</ref> Despite this, the opposition parties CAP 2015 and the Pan-African National Party started a large three-day protest in Lomé.<ref name="80 arrested"/> [[Amnesty International]] estimated that about 100,000 people participated in a protest on 6 September.<ref name="internet restored"/> At least 80 protesters were arrested on 7 September for "preparing to commit violent acts, vandalise shops."<ref name="80 arrested">{{cite news |last=Akwei |first=Ismali |url=http://www.africanews.com/2017/09/09/at-least-80-arrested-after-togo-s-latest-anti-government-protests/ |title=At least 80 arrested after Togo's latest anti-government protests |date=9 September 2017 |work=Africanews |accessdate=23 December 2017}}</ref> Security forces in Lomé fired [[tear gas]] to disperse the protesters.<ref>{{cite news |last=Zodzi |first=John |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-togo-protests/togo-blocks-internet-as-protesters-march-for-second-day-idUSKCN1BI1UT |title=Togo forces fire tear gas to disperse Gnassingbe opponents |date=7 September 2017 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> Normal access to the internet was restored on 11 September.<ref name="internet restored">{{cite news |url=http://read.unitednews.international/2017/09/12/internet-restored-togo-protests/ |title=Internet Restored After Togo Protests |date=12 September 2017 |work=United News International |accessdate=23 December 2017}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.africareview.com/news/Second-day-of-mass-protests-in-Togo/979180-4086610-7hfg64z/index.html |title=Second day of mass protests in Togo |work=Africa Review |date=7 September 2017 |agency=AFP |accessdate=23 December 2017}}</ref> The United Nations urged the Togolese government to address the "legitimate expectations" of the protesters.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/09/urges-togo-respond-protesters-expectations-170909053453123.html |title=UN urges Togo to respond to protesters' 'expectations' |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=9 September 2017 |accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref>
Togo's [[National Assembly (Togo)|National Assembly]] introduced a bill meant to reform the country's electoral system and introduce presidential term limits of two five-year terms. The opposition objected to the bill's wording, saying that the term limits would not be retroactive. The opposition boycotted the National Assembly's vote on the bill on 18 September, making it subject to a referendum.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/togos-opposition-boycotts-constitutional-reform-vote-20170919 |title=Togo's opposition boycotts constitutional reform vote |work=[[News24]] |date=19 September 2017 |accessdate=31 December 2017}}</ref> The next day, the Togolese government slowed down the country's internet as the opposition prepared for more protests.<ref>{{cite news |last=Akwei |first=Ismail |url=http://www.africanews.com/2017/09/20/internet-slowdown-in-togo-ahead-of-another-presidential-limits-protest/ |title=Internet slowdown in Togo ahead of another presidential limits protest |work=Africanews |date=9 September 2017 |accessdate=30 December 2017}}</ref> According to [[Amnesty International]], security forces used batons, bullets, and tear gas against protesters in [[Mango, Togo|Mango]], killing a 9-year-old boy.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Zodzi |first1=John |last2=Wilkins |first2=Henry |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-togo-protests/togo-security-forces-clash-with-protesters-in-north-killing-boy-idUSKCN1BV31E |title=Togo security forces clash with protesters in north, boy killed |date=20 September 2017 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=31 December 2017}}</ref> Security minister Damehane Yark blamed the opposition for the boy's death, saying the protesters were using weapons.<ref>{{cite news |last=Akwei |first=Ismail |url=http://www.africanews.com/2017/09/21/10-year-old-boy-killed-in-renewed-togo-protest-govt-blames-opposition |title=10-year-old boy killed in renewed Togo protest, govt blames opposition |work=Africanews |date=21 September 2017 |accessdate=30 December 2017}}</ref> A picture of a cow killed by the military in the village [[Kparatao]] spread online and became a symbol of the protests.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/1169701/world |title=Togo: Protests, a dead cow and a political message |work=Arab News |date=29 September 2017 |agency=AFP |accessdate=31 December 2017}}</ref> The next day, opposition leaders blamed the government for repressing protests in Northern Togo, and thousands of Togolese participated in anti-government demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.ug/thousands-join-fresh-protests-togo-amid-crackdown/ |title=Thousands join fresh protests in Togo amid 'crackdown' |date=23 September 2017 |publisher=The Independent Uganda |agency=AFP |accessdate=31 December 2017}}</ref>
===October 2017=== On 3 October, the United States embassy in Togo issued a security warning concerning transportation issues that could arise because of upcoming protests.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.africanews.com/2017/10/04/togo-anti-gnassingbe-protest-holds-amid-us-security-alert/ |title=Togo anti-Gnassingbe protest holds amid U.S. security alert |date=4 October 2017 |work=Africanews |accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref> On 4 and 5 October, thousands of protesters marched through Lomé and some created barricades. In response, the Togolese government shut down internet communication and mobile access to the internet.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/thousands-march-on-second-day-of-togo-protests-20171005 |title=Thousands march on second day of Togo protests |work=News24 |agency=AFP |date=5 October 2017 |accessdate=25 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/people-protesting-togo-171004103544908.html |title=Why are people protesting in Togo? |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=5 October 2017 |accessdate=25 December 2017}}</ref> The Togolese government announced a ban on weekday protests on 10 October, though opposition parties said they would defy this ban.<ref>{{cite news |last=Shaban |first=Abdur Rahman Alfa |url=http://www.africanews.com/2017/10/11/togo-bans-weekday-protests-as-opposition-vows-anti-ecowas-march/ |title=Togo bans weekday protests as opposition vows anti-ECOWAS march |work=Africanews |agency=AFP |date=11 October 2017 |accessdate=25 December 2017}}</ref>
Alpha Alassane, an imam affiliated with the opposition movement, was arrested in [[Sokodé]] on 16 October for allegedly inciting violence with his followers. The arrest fueled tension between the Togolese government and the opposition.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/1178896/world |title=Violent clashes in northern Togo after imam arrested |work=Arab News |date=17 October 2017 |agency=AFP |accessdate=25 December 2017}}</ref> A two-day protests started on 18 October throughout Togo. On the first day, four people—one in [[Lomé]] and three in [[Sokodé]]—were reportedly killed during clashes between protesters and security forces.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dw.com/en/deadly-protests-in-togo-against-president-faure-gnassingbes-continued-rule/a-41022973 |title=Deadly protests in Togo against President Faure Gnassingbe's continued rule |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=18 October 2017 |accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201710190141.html |title=Togo: Four Killed During Protests Against Gnassingbé |date=19 October 2017 |accessdate=25 December 2017 |work=AllAfrica |agency=RFI}}</ref> Yark Damehame, Togo's security minister, denied the reported deaths, saying that nobody was killed in Sokodé on this day.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20171020-togo-deny-deaths-protests-clashes-ecowas-president-gnassingbe |title=Togo officials deny reports of deaths in new anti-regime protests |work=France 24 |date=20 October 2017 |agency=AFP |accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref> Some protesters in Lomé formed barricades, and police fired tear gas to disperse them.<ref>{{cite news |last=Woussou |first=Kossi |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-18/togo-police-fire-teargas-as-opposition-vow-to-resume-protests |title=Togo Police Fire Teargas as Opposition Vows to Press Protests |date=18 October 2017 |work=Bloomberg |accessdate=31 December 2017}}</ref> About 300 Togolese nationals attempted to participate in a protest in [[Accra]], [[Ghana]], but the police ruled the demonstration was unlawful and arrested 26 protesters.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mensah |first=Duke Opoku |url=https://citifmonline.com/2017/10/28/26-togolese-arrested-for-illegal-protest-in-accra/ |title=26 Togolese arrested for illegal protest in Accra |publisher=[[Citi FM (Ghana)|Citi FM]] |date=28 October 2017 |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref>
[[Foreign Minister of Gambia|Gambia's Foreign Minister]] [[Ousainou Darboe]] called on Gnassingbe to resign,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.africanews.com/2017/10/23/au-ecowas-must-persuade-togo-president-to-resign-gambian-top-diplomat/ |title=Togo president must resign immediately - Gambian Foreign Minister |work=Africanews |agency=Reuters |access-date=4 January 2018 |language=en}}</ref> although he retracted the statement a few days later and said it was a matter for the Togolese people.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-togo/togos-president-gnassingbe-should-resign-immediately-gambian-foreign-minister-idUSKBN1CS1W7 |title=Gambian ministry says up to Togo to resolve crisis |date=23 October 2017 |work=Reuters |access-date=4 January 2018}}</ref> [[U.S. Department of State]] spokesperson [[Heather Nauert]] called on the Togolese government to protect its citizens' rights and engage in dialogue with the protesters.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.premiumtimesng.com/foreign/west-africa-foreign/247208-u-s-expresses-concerns-rising-levels-violence-restrictions-togo.html |title=U.S. expresses concerns over rising levels of violence, restrictions in Togo |date=25 October 2017 |work=[[Premium Times]] |accessdate=30 December 2017}}</ref>
===November 2017=== The Togolese government lifted its ban on weekday protests on 4 November.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.trtworld.com/africa/protest-ban-scrapped-in-togo-11942 |title=Protest ban scrapped in Togo |publisher=TRT World |date=4 November 2017 |accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref> On 7 November the Togolese government released 42 of the protesters who were arrested in September and dropped arson charges against opposition leader [[Jean-Pierre Fabre]]. Opposition parties saw this as an attempt to appease their demands.<ref>{{cite news |last=Akwei |first=Ismail |url=http://www.africanews.com/2017/11/07/togo-releases-42-detained-protesters-drops-2013-case-against-opposition-leader/ |title=Togo releases 42 detained protesters, drops 2013 case against opposition leader |work=Africanews |date=7 November 2017 |accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref> Thousands of protesters participated in three protests during this week, with the last one on 10 November.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.enca.com/africa/opposition-march-again-in-togo-over-political-reform |title=Opposition march again in Togo over political reform |publisher=eNCA |agency=AFP |accessdate=30 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20171110-togo-protests-continue-amid-stalemate-concerns |title=Togo anti-government protesters vow to continue push for term limits |work=France 24 |date=10 November 2017 |agency=AFP |accessdate=30 December 2017}}</ref>
Gnassingbé blamed the opposition for violence at its protests.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.enca.com/africa/togo-president-blames-opposition-for-violence |title=Togo president blames opposition for violence |work=ENCA.com |date=11 November 2017 |accessdate=25 December 2017}}</ref> Opposition leaders called this a "declaration of war" against the Togolese people.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/togo-opposition-says-presidents-claim-a-declaration-of-war-20171114 |title=Togo opposition says president's claim a 'declaration of war' |work=News24 |agency=AFP |date=14 November 2017 |accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref> Gnassingbé visited Sokodé in late November 2017, saying, "My exchanges with the imams and senior figures left me reassured that our country remains indivisible."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/togos-president-visits-opposition-stronghold-after-protests-20171127 |title=Togo's president visits opposition stronghold after protests |work=News24 |agency=AFP |date=27 November 2017 |accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref>
===December 2017=== The [[Economic Community of West African States]] (ECOWAS) held its 2017 summit on 16 December in [[Abuja]], [[Nigeria]] instead of in Togo, likely because of political tension between the government and opposition.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://en.yabiladi.com/articles/details/59628/togo-gives-hosting-ecowas-summit.html |title=Togo gives up hosting the ECOWAS summit set to announce Morocco's accession |date=24 November 2017 |work=Yabiladi |accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref> Around the time of this summit, thousands of protesters held anti-government marches.<ref name=Vanguard>{{cite news |url=https://www.vanguardngr.com/2017/12/protests-togo-president-chairs-ecowas-summit/ |title=More protests in Togo as president chairs ECOWAS summit |date=16 December 2017 |work=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)|Vanguard]] |accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref> In [[Accra]], Ghana, police arrested twelve members of the Ghana–Togo Solidarity movement, including Bernard Mornah, the chairman of the [[People's National Convention (Ghana)|People's National Convention]], for protesting the situation in Togo.<ref>{{cite news |last=Nyabor |first=Jonas |url=https://citifmonline.com/2017/12/16/pncs-bernard-mornah-12-others-arrested-for-illegal-march/ |title=PNC's Bernard Mornah, 12 others arrested for ‘illegal march’ |publisher=Citi FM |date=16 December 2017 |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref>
The opposition held demonstrations on 28 December, and the police arrest of a young man was filmed.<ref>{{cite news |last=Amouzou |first=Georges |url=http://observers.france24.com/fr/20171229-togo-lome-manifestations-jeune-police |title=Manifestations au Togo : un jeune frappé et arrêté après avoir filmé les forces de l'ordre |work=Les Observateurs |publisher=France 24 |date=29 December 2017 |accessdate=10 January 2018}}</ref> Tens of thousands of opposition supporters protested peacefully in Lomé on 31 December.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/article/31/12/2017/Thousands-gather-in-Togo-to-protest-president |title=Thousands gather in Togo to protest president |newspaper=[[The Peninsula (newspaper)|The Peninsula]] |date=31 December 2017 |accessdate=3 January 2018}}</ref>
===January 2018=== On 3 January 2018, Gnassingbé called for the opposition to participate in government talks to resolve their differences.<ref>{{cite news |last=Shaban |first=Abdur Rahman Alfa |url=http://www.africanews.com/2018/01/04/togo-president-reiterates-political-dialogue-call-in-new-year-message/ |title=Togo president reiterates political dialogue call in New Year message |work=Africanews |date=4 January 2018 |accessdate=8 January 2018}}</ref> Thousands of people in Togo participated in an anti-government protest on 13 January 2018, the 55th anniversary of the [[Sylvanus Olympio]]'s assassination. Counter-protesters held demonstrations in support of the government. Supporters of the Togolese opposition also protested in [[Berlin]] and [[Washington, DC]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.enca.com/africa/opposition-and-ruling-party-supporters-march-in-togo |title=Anti government protest hits Togo |work=ENCA |agency=AFP |date=14 January 2018 |accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Wong |first=Dwayne |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/the-togolese-people-protest-on-the-anniversary-of-sylvanus_us_5a5a67b7e4b003efadb6ae5e |title=The Togolese People Protest on the Anniversary of Sylvanus Olympio's Assassination |work=HuffPost |date=13 January 2018 |accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref>
On 20 January 2018, the same day as the [[2018 Women's March]], the opposition held an anti-government demonstration focused on female involvement.<ref>{{cite news |last=Akwei |first=Ismail |url=https://face2faceafrica.com/article/womens-march-also-held-togo-different-dictator |title=Women's March was also held in Togo - but against a different dictator |work=[[Face2Face Africa]] |date=January 21, 2018 |accessdate=January 22, 2018}}</ref> During the protest, thousands of Togolese women mostly dressed in black marched through Lomé, accompanied by male opposition supporters.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/thousands-of-women-in-anti-president-protest-in-togo-20180121 |title=Thousands of women in anti-president protest in Togo |work=News24 |agency=AFP |date=21 January 2018 |accessdate=22 January 2018}}</ref> Starting on 31 January 2018, Togolese healthcare workers went on a two-day strike to demand that the government provide better health services.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/togo-healthcare-workers-join-strike-as-protests-mount-20180131 |title=Togo healthcare workers join strike as protests mount |work=News24 |agency=AFP |date=31 January 2018 |accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>
===February 2018=== On 15 February, [[Amnesty International]], [[Front Line Defenders]] and [[Africans Rising]] issued a joint statement criticising Togo's treatment of activists involved in the protests.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://citizen.co.za/news/news-africa/1821493/togo-politique-diplomatie/ |title=Rights groups warn Togo over campaign against protest leaders |work=The Citizen |agency=AFP |date=15 February 2018 |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref>
In early February 2018, the opposition agreed to stop holding protests while mediators from [[Guinea]] and [[Ghana]] visited Togo.<ref>{{cite news |last=Woussou |first=Kossi |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-02/togo-opposition-to-halt-protests-as-regional-mediators-arrive |title=Togo Opposition to Halt Protests as Regional Mediators Arrive |date=2 February 2018 |work=Bloomberg |accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref> However, on 4 February 2018, the day after these mediators suggested that Togo hold talks on constitutional reform, thousands of protesters marched through Lomé.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.africanews.com/2018/02/04/togo-capital-hit-by-anti-govt-protest-despite-dialogue-deal |title=Togo capital hit by anti-govt protest despite dialogue deal |work=Africanews |agency=AFP |date=4 February 2018 |accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref> Ghanaian President [[Nana Akufo-Addo]] and Guinean President [[Alpha Condé]] started mediating talks between the Togolese government and opposition on 19 February in Lomé.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/world/2018/feb/19/talks-open-in-togo-between-government-and-opposition-1775854.html |title=Talks open in Togo between government and opposition |work=The New Indian Express |agency=AFP |date=19 February 2018 |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref> The next day, Ghanaian mediators announced that the Togolese government would released 45 of the 92 people imprisoned for participating in the protests.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.republicoftogo.com/Toutes-les-rubriques/In-English/Demonstrations-suspended-45-detainees-released |title=Demonstrations suspended, 45 detainees released |work=République Togolaise |date=20 February 2018 |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref>
===March 2018=== On 6 March, Togo's opposition coalition announced it would resume protests, despite the previous agreement to suspend protests while government talks were underway. Eric Dupuy, the coalition spokesman, said this was because the Togolese government failed to prepare for upcoming parliamentary elections.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/togo-opposition-announces-resumption-of-protest-demos-20180306 |title=Togo opposition announces resumption of protest demos |work=News24 |agency=AFP |date=6 March 2018 |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref> Ghanaian President Akufo-Addo met with 14 Togolese opposition leaders on the next day at [[The Flagstaff House]] in [[Accra]], Ghana.<ref>{{cite news |last=Afful |first=Maame Aba |url=https://www.primenewsghana.com/general-news/akufo-addo-meets-14-togolese-opposition-parties-today.html |title=Akufo-Addo meets 14 Togolese opposition parties today |work=Prime News Ghana |date=7 March 2018 |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref> Two days later, this opposition coalition accepted the Akufo-Addo's request to continue suspending protests for the next week while the talks continued.<ref>{{cite news |title=Togo opposition suspends protests at Ghana request |url=https://www.independent.co.ug/togo-opposition-suspends-protests-at-ghana-request/ |work=The Independent Uganda |agency=AFP |date=10 March 2018 |accessdate=16 March 2018}}</ref> These talks resumed on 23 March.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://guardian.ng/news/talks-resume-between-togo-government-and-opposition/ |title=Talks resume between Togo government and opposition |agency=AFP |work=The Guardian |date=23 March 2018 |accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref>
===April 2018=== The opposition coalition planned protests in Lomé and other towns on 11–12 April, and the Togolese government said this would violate their agreement with Akufo-Addo. On the first day of this demonstration, the police fired tear gas on the protesters.<ref>{{cite news |last=Shaban |first=Abdur Rahman Alfa |url=http://www.africanews.com/2018/04/11/togo-police-crack-down-on-anti-government-protesters/ |title=Togo police crack down on anti-government protesters |work=Africanews |date=11 April 2018 |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref> On 14 April 2018, security forces in Lomé fired tear gas near the headquarters of the [[Democratic Convention of African Peoples]]<ref>{{cite news |last=Kriesch |first=Adrian |url=https://www.dw.com/en/togo-protests-break-out-despite-ban/a-43404037 |publisher=Deutsche Welle |title=Togo: Protests break out despite ban |date=16 April 2018 |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref><ref name="Leaders meet GNA">{{cite news |url=https://gulfnews.com/news/africa/west-african-leaders-meet-in-bid-to-defuse-togo-crisis-1.2205687 |title=West African leaders meet in bid to defuse Togo crisis |date=15 April 2018 |work=[[Gulf News]] |agency=AFP |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref> About 25 people were injured during these three days of protest, and one person died from his injuries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mfwa.org/country-highlights/one-person-killed-as-togolese-opposition-resume-protests-amidst-another-crackdown/ |title=One Person Killed as Togolese Opposition Resume Protests Amidst Another Crackdown |publisher=[[Media Foundation for West Africa]] |date=19 April 2018 |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref> Security forces also prevented people from protesting in [[Kpalimé]]. Heads of state in ECOWAS held talks in Lomé on this day, and they called on Akufo-Addo and Condé to step up their reform efforts and end political violence.<ref name="Leaders meet GNA"/>
===May 2018–present=== The opposition coalition parties announced on 8 May that they were calling off protests planned in the coming days, citing the lack of security and progress with their objectives.<ref>{{cite news |last=Muisyo |first=Victor |url=http://www.africanews.com/2018/05/09/togo-opposition-coalition-calls-off-planned-protest/ |title=Togo: opposition coalition calls off planned protest |work=Africanews |date=9 May 2018 |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref> On 17 June, the coalition called for its supporters to participate in a sit-at-home general strike the next day, and the government urged people to boycott this protest.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mbah |first=Fidelis |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/06/togo-opposition-calls-stay-home-protests-180616202606895.html |title=Togo opposition calls for stay-at-home protests |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=17 June 2018 |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref>
The Togolese government and opposition coalition held talks on 27 June, and Akufo-Addo and Condé, the co-facilitators of these talks, called for continued dialogue and suspended street protests.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.myjoyonline.com/politics/2018/June-28th/akufo-addo-conde-urge-togo-politicians-to-suspend-street-protests.php |title=Akufo-Addo, Conde urge Togo politicians to suspend street protests |website=MyJoyOnline.com |date=28 June 2018 |accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref> The government banned street protests from 23 July to 1 August while Togo hosted an ECOWAS summit.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kaledzi |first1=Isaac |title=Togo bans street protests amid political tension |url=https://africafeeds.com/2018/07/22/togo-bans-street-protests-amid-political-tension/ |accessdate=3 September 2018 |work=Africa Feeds |date=22 July 2018}}</ref> On November 3, 2018, over a thousand people protested in Lomé to demand the release of imprisoned protesters.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.modernghana.com/news/895136/hundreds-march-in-togo-for-release-of-protesters.html |title=Hundreds march in Togo for release of protesters |work=Modern Ghana |agency=AFP |date=3 November 2018 |accessdate=5 November 2018}}</ref>

{{Primary sources|article|date=January 2016}} '''African Well Fund''' is a [[non-profit organization]] dedicated to raising funds for the construction and maintenance of freshwater wells throughout impoverished sections of [[Africa]]. It was founded in October 2002 by a group of [[U2]] fans who were inspired by frontman [[Bono|Bono's]] May 2002 visit to poor sections of [[Africa]] along with former [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|U.S. Secretary of the Treasury]] [[Paul O'Neill (businessman)|Paul O'Neill]]. The organization was inspired by [[Bono|Bono's]] charitable work throughout Africa, but is not directly connected to the band.
The organization is partnered with [[Africare]], and is staffed entirely by volunteers to minimize overhead.
Although most of the donations come from North Americans and Western Europeans that are not actually there to observe the people benefiting from their help, leaps towards progress occurred in African communities due to global concern and global participation, as well as cooperation and understanding amongst the people.<ref name=":0">{{Citation|last=Steve Buckwalter|title=African Well Fund|date=2007-03-28|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y-5U3JWVvdw|accessdate=2017-11-21}}</ref>
== History == Take one of the first well projects that cost a mere one thousand dollars. Access to water in southern Uganda in 2002 was limited due to the [[Second Congo War|Great African War.]] It must have been a terrifying place to go out to get water for your mother, and your siblings. Children or their mothers in the village of Ntungamo had to travel long distances through the district to collect water for bathing and cooking. But, the water sources were stagnant, just holes in the ground. People often bathed in them, and children just cleaned the algae off of the surface of the water when collecting it. This spread disease in an area of the world where HIV/AIDS is often a taboo topic of discussion, and people are not always properly educated about the severity of the issue because of this.<ref name=":0" />
The construction of a well with running water actually helped bring people together, and Africare water experts were able to educate people about the issue of HIV/AIDS, as well as how important it is to do their part in maintaining the well.
== Celebrity involvement == By donating money and spreading awareness about issues that people may be struggling with far away, people often feel more connected with the people they're trying to help. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mitchell|first=Katharyne|date=2016-07-01|title=Celebrity humanitarianism, transnational emotion and the rise of neoliberal citizenship|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/glob.12114/abstract|journal=Global Networks|language=en|volume=16|issue=3|pages=288–306|doi=10.1111/glob.12114|issn=1471-0374}}</ref>For Bono's 50th birthday, U2 fans attempted to raise 50,000 dollars for the Buhara District in Zimbabwe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.u2.com/news/title/walk-to-the-water/news/|title=U2 > News > Walk To The Water|website=www.u2.com|access-date=2017-12-06}}</ref>

{{about||the US politician whose Chinese name is Zhou Yongkang|Charles Djou|a former leader of [[Chinese Communist Party]]|Zhou Yongkang}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Alex Chow Yong-kang | native_name = | image = 香港雨傘運動學生領袖周永康.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Chow on grant of bail, 7 October 2017 | birth_date = 1990 | birth_place = | occupation = [[Social activist]] | net_worth = | website = }} [[File:Alex_Chow_Yong-kang.jpg|thumb|Alex Chow in February 2015, organized the Front for Democracy march{{source?|date=October 2017}}]] '''Alex Chow Yong-kang''' ({{zh|t=周永康|sl=Jau<sup>1</sup> Wing<sup>5</sup> Hong<sup>1</sup>}}; born 1990) is a [[social activist]] in [[Hong Kong]], a former student of the Faculty of Arts of the [[University of Hong Kong]] and former [[secretary-general]] of the [[Hong Kong Federation of Students]].<ref name = guard>{{cite web|last1=Kaiman|first1=Jonathan|title=Who guides Hong Kong’s ‘Umbrella Revolution’ pro-democracy movement?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/30/hong-kong-pro-democracy-protest-leaders-occupy| work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=25 October 2014|date=30 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Liao|first1=Mei Hong|script-title=zh:特稿：让习近平烦心的两个周永康|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/zhongwen/simp/china/2014/10/141024_hongkong_china_zhou-yongkang|publisher= [[BBC]] |accessdate=25 October 2014|language=Chinese|date=24 October 2014}}</ref> He was the Vice-President (External) of the [[Hong Kong University Students' Union]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Delegation to Hong Kong Federation of Students|url=http://www.council.hkusu.hku.hk/DHKFS.html|publisher= Hong Kong University Students' Union|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref>
==Occupy Central== [[File:Occupy Central 2 October 2014 - Alex Chow.jpg|thumb|Alex Chow addresses Occupy Central Crowd, 2 October 2014 17:54]] He was one of the main organizers of the [[Occupy Central with Love and Peace|Occupy Central]] campaign.<ref name=LAT>{{cite web|last1=Makinen|first1=Julie|last2=Law|first2=Violet|title=2 Hong Kong college students emerge as leaders in mass protest|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-hong-kong-leaders-20141006-story.html#page=1|work= [[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=25 October 2014|date=5 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Wen|first1=Philip|title=Hong Kong protests: Key players from Joshua Wong to Leung Chun-ying|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/hong-kong-protests-key-players-from-joshua-wong-to-leung-chunying-20141001-10ot6j.html|work= [[Sydney Morning Herald]] |accessdate=25 October 2014|date=1 October 2014}}</ref> On 1 July 2014, following an annual pro-democracy rally, he organised a sit-in on [[Chater Road]] in central Hong Kong which was forcibly dispersed by police.<ref>{{cite web|script-title=zh:周永康：佔領遮打道為日後「佔中」姿態 |url=http://singpao.com/xw/yw/201407/t20140702_516380.html |work=[[Sing Pao]] |accessdate=25 October 2014 |language=Chinese |date=2 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141025085556/http://singpao.com/xw/yw/201407/t20140702_516380.html |archivedate=25 October 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Joyce|first1=Ng|last2=Jesse|first2=Lau|title=Democracy protesters arrested at Chater Road sit-in will refuse to renew their bail|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1562629/democracy-protesters-arrested-chater-road-sit-will-refuse-renew-their?page=all|work= [[South China Morning Post]] |accessdate=25 October 2014|date=30 July 2014}}</ref> 511 people were arrested. He was quoted as saying at the time that "It’s not enough to repeat the march and the assembly every year. We have to upgrade it to a civil disobedience movement." He later wrote that "In the past 30 years, the democracy movement has been too slow and too painstaking. The power of civil disobedience lies … in the blood and tears of everyone who is behind the struggle."<ref name=LAT/>
==Umbrella Movement== [[File:Alex Chow Yong Kang 2014.jpg|thumb|Alex Chow addresses protesters]] In the early stages of the [[Umbrella Movement]], he was an influential organiser and speaker. He was reported as announcing to protesters, "This is not a student movement; this is a Hong Kongers' movement"; he warned the ''[[New York Times]]'' that "residents may occupy various government departments".<ref name = guard/><ref name=LAT/> On 5 October, when the Federation of Students agreed to enter into dialogue with the government, Chow announced that the talks would be called off if attempts were made to forcefully remove protesters. In a speech at the main protest camp, he explained, "A dialogue is not a compromise. We will start arranging talks with the government, because we understand that there are people in both the government and here who want to solve society’s problems. We will not back down."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/06/world/asia/hong-kong-protests.html|title=Protesters in Hong Kong Ease Sit-In Near Government Headquarters|work= [[New York Times]] |author=Keith Bradshaw and Chris Buckley|date=5 October 2014|accessdate=2014-11-02}}</ref>
Having attempted and failed to organise meetings with officials through local channels,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=4&art_id=151221&sid=43333705&con_type=1&d_str=20141110&fc=1 |title=Students urge NPC deputies to intercede |author=Kenneth Lau |date=10 November 2014 |work=[[The Standard (Hong Kong)|Standard]] |publisher=[[Sing Tao News Corporation|Sing Tao]] |accessdate=2017-06-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141110044835/http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=4&art_id=151221&sid=43333705&con_type=1&d_str=20141110&fc=1 |archivedate=10 November 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/news/asia/east-asia/story/ex-hong-kong-chief-exec-tung-chee-hwa-says-china-wont-change-mind-democrac|title=Ex-Hong Kong Chief Exec Tung Chee Hwa says China won't change mind on democracy: Paper | work = [[The Straits Times|Straits Times]] | publisher = [[Singapore Press Holdings|Singapore Press]] | date = 9 November 2014 | accessdate = 2017-06-07 }}</ref> Chow and two other students were prevented from travelling to China to petition mainland government officials when they attempted to leave on 15 November.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-30067035|title=Hong Kong protest leaders denied Beijing flight|publisher= [[BBC]] |date=15 November 2014|accessdate=16 November 2014}}</ref> The group, consisting of Chow, [[Nathan Law]] and Eason Chung, learned from airline officials that mainland authorities had revoked their [[Home Return Permit]]s, effectively banning them from boarding the flight for Beijing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1640648/occupy-leaders-seeking-travel-beijing-denied-boarding-airport-cathay|title=Beijing bans student leaders from taking trip to mainland to press for democracy|work= [[South China Morning Post]] | author1 = Joyce Ng | author2 = Amy Nip | author3 = Stuart Lau | date = 15 November 2014 | accessdate = 2017-06-07 }}</ref>
Chow and two other prominent Hong Kong pro-democracy student leaders, [[Nathan Law]] and [[Joshua Wong (activist)|Joshua Wong]], were convicted on 21 July 2016 of unlawful assembly (incitement in Chow's case) at the [[Civic Square (Hong Kong)|Civic Square]], [[Central Government Complex]] at [[Tamar, Hong Kong|Tamar]], during a protest that triggered the 79-day Occupy sit-ins of 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests-verdict/teenage-hong-kong-protest-leader-found-guilty-of-unlawful-assembly-idUSKCN1010BB?il=0|title=Teenage Hong Kong protest leader found guilty of unlawful assembly|date=21 July 2016|newspaper=Reuters|last1=Long|first1=Lindsy|last2=Poon|first2=Hera|access-date=28 October 2017}}</ref> After initially being sentenced to three weeks' imprisonment (suspended) on 15 August 2016, his term was increased a year later to seven months on appeal to the High Court by the government.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/09/01/democracy-activist-alex-chow-files-appeal-jail-sentence/|title=Hong Kong democracy activist Alex Chow files appeal over jail sentence|date=1 September 2017|newspaper=Hong Kong Free Press|last=Pang|first=Jun|access-date=28 October 2017}}</ref> The conviction, if not overturned on appeal, would result in disqualification from standing for election to the Legislative Council until July 2021.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hklii.org/eng/hk/legis/ord/542/s39.html|title=CAP 542 LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL ORDINANCE Section 39 When person is disqualified from being nominated as a candidate and from being elected as a Member|website=Hong Kong Legal Information Institute|access-date=28 October 2017}}</ref>
Chow began a master's degree at the [[London School of Economics]] in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/14/hong-kong-student-alex-chow-fears-uk-visa-denied-umbrella-protest|title=Hong Kong student fears UK visa may be denied over protest conviction |date=14 September 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|last=Phillips|first=Tom|access-date=28 October 2017}}</ref>
== Nobel Peace Prize nomination ==
On 1 February 2018, a bipartisan group of US lawmakers, led by [[Congressional-Executive Commission on China]] (CECC) Chair US Senator [[Marco Rubio]] and co-chair US Representative [[Chris Smith (New Jersey politician) |Chris Smith]] announced they had nominated<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2018/02/01/group-us-lawmakers-nominate-hong-kongs-umbrella-movement-nobel-peace-prize/|title=Group of US lawmakers nominate Hong Kong’s Umbrella Movement for Nobel Peace Prize|newspaper=Hong Kong Free Press|date=1 February 2018|last=Lai|first=Catherine|access-date=2 February 2018}}</ref> [[Joshua Wong (activist)|Joshua Wong]], [[Nathan Law]], Chow and the entire [[Umbrella Movement]] for the 2018 [[Nobel Peace Prize]], for "their peaceful efforts to bring political reform and protect the autonomy and freedoms guaranteed Hong Kong in the Sino-British Joint Declaration".<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=5 October 2017 |title=Chairs Release 2017 Annual Report--Announce New Initiatives on Hong Kong & Commemoration of Liu Xiaobo |url=https://www.cecc.gov/media-center/press-releases/chairs-release-2017-annual-report |work= | |website=Congressional-Executive Commission on China |location=Washington, DC |access-date= 7 October 2017 }}</ref>

The '''Aufbau Vereinigung''' (Reconstruction Organisation) was a [[Munich]]-based counterrevolutionary conspiratorial group formed in the aftermath of the [[Ukrainian War of Independence|German occupation of the Ukraine in 1918]] and of the [[West Russian Volunteer Army|Latvian Intervention of 1919]]. It brought together [[White movement|White Russian]] émigrés and early German [[National Socialists]] who aimed to overthrow the governments of Germany and the Soviet Union, replacing them with authoritarian régimes of the far right. The group was originally known as Die Bruecke (The Bridge). ''Aufbau'' was also the name of a periodical it brought out.<ref>Russia and Germany, A Century of Conflict by [[Walter Laqueur]] London, Weidenfeld and Nicolson 1965. p76</ref>
According to Michael Kellogg,<ref>The Russian Roots of Nazism White Émigrés and the Making of National Socialism, 1917–1945 by Michael Kellogg, Cambridge 2005</ref> the Aufbau Vereinigung was a vital influence on the development of Nazi ideology in the years before the [[Beer Hall Putsch]] of 1923 as well as financing NSDAP with, for example, funds from [[Henry Ford]]. It gave [[Hitler]] the idea of a vast Jewish conspiracy, involving a close alliance between international finance and [[Bolshevism]] and threatening disaster for mankind.<ref>Kellogg p278</ref> Recent research on Hitler's early years in [[Vienna]] (1905-1913) appears to have shown that his [[antisemitism]] was at that time far less developed than it became under the new influences.<ref>Hitler's Vienna: A Dictator's Apprenticeship by Brigitte Hamann New York: Oxford University Press, 1999. pp. 347-359.</ref>
Aufbau members became involved in terrorist activities, including the assassination of [[Walther Rathenau]] and that of [[Vladimir Dmitrievich Nabokov]] (both in 1922).<ref>Kellogg p. 276</ref>
After the death of [[Scheubner-Richter]] in the putsch, Aufbau rapidly declined, and notions of [[Lebensraum]] and [[Untermensch|Slavic inferiority]], naturally unpopular with the Russians, gained a stronger hold on the Nazi movement.<ref>Laqueur pp79 & 89</ref>
The long-term influence of Aufbau has been traced{{by whom?|date=December 2015}} in the implementation of the [[final solution]]<ref>Kellogg P 241</ref> and in Hitler's disastrous decision to divert troops away from Moscow towards the Ukraine in 1941.<ref>Kellogg p279</ref>
Prominent members of Aufbau included: *[[Max Erwin von Scheubner-Richter]] (a Baltic German from the Russian Empire) *[[Alfred Rosenberg]] (a Baltic German from the Russian Empire) *[[Fyodor Viktorovich Vinberg|Fyodor Vinberg]] (Russian officer) *[[Piotr Shabelsky-Bork]] (Russian officer) *General [[Vasily Biskupsky]] (Russian officer) *[[Erich Ludendorff]] *[[Max Amann]] *[[Boris Brasol]] (Russian émigré)

{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox political party | name = Australian Liberty Alliance | logo = Australian Liberty Alliance party logo.png | colorcode = navy | leader = | president = Debbie Robinson | chairman = | general_secretary = | first_secretary = | secretary_general = | presidium = | secretary = Ralf Schumann | spokesperson = | foundation = {{start date|2015}} | ideology = [[Australian nationalism]]
[[Conservatism in Australia|Conservatism]]
[[Economic liberalism]]
[[Right-wing populism]]
[[Anti-Islam]]https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/australian-liberty-alliance-the-antiislam-donald-trumpstyle-party-claims-major-growth-20160406-go08lq.html | headquarters = [[South Melbourne]], [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]], 3205 | international = | website = {{URL|australianlibertyalliance.org.au}} | country = Australia | abbreviation = ALA | colours = {{Color box|RED|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|WHITE|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|BLUE|border=darkgray}} Red, white, blue | position = [[Right-wing]] to [[far-right]] }} The '''Australian Liberty Alliance''' (ALA) is a [[right-wing]] micro party in Australia. The party was registered with the [[Australian Electoral Commission]] (AEC) on 28 July 2015.{{cite web|title=Australian Liberty Alliance|url=http://www.aec.gov.au/Parties_and_Representatives/party_registration/Registered_parties/aust-liberty-alliance.htm|website=Australian Electoral Commission|accessdate=21 May 2016}} The party held its official launch on 20 October 2015 at a private function in [[Perth]], Western Australia, with controversial Dutch politician [[Geert Wilders]] and British anti-sharia activist [[Anne Marie Waters]] as keynote speakers.{{cite news|title=Australian Liberty Alliance: Geert Wilders unveils Senate candidates amid warnings over 'blatant racism'|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-10-21/australian-liberty-alliance-candidates-unveiled-amid-racism-fear/6874336|accessdate=21 May 2016|publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |location=Australia|date=22 October 2015}}. On 1 October 2018 ALA was also registered as state party in Victoria. https://www.vec.vic.gov.au/CandidatesAndParties/CurrentRegisteredParties.html. Senator [[Fraser Anning]] (QLD) attended the party's Victorian campaign launch as keynote speaker https://vimeo.com/297224488. ==Electoral History== {{see also|Results of the Australian federal election, 2016 (House of Representatives)}} {{see also|Senate results for the Australian federal election, 2016}} In May 2016 the party endorsed [[Angry Anderson]] as a candidate for the [[Australian Senate|Senate]] representing New South Wales at the [[Australian federal election, 2016|2016 federal election]].{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/09/suddenly-singer-angry-anderson-is-now-candidate-for-anti-islamic/ |title=Anderson is now candidate for anti-Islamic political party |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location=England |date=9 May 2016 |accessdate=4 June 2016 |author=Boult, Adam}}{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/angry-anderson-joins-antiislam-party-to-chase-a-senate-seat-at-the-federal-election/news-story/cf23fd04d6e709c99d5feaeacb818f11 |title=Angry Anderson joins anti-Islam party to chase a Senate seat at the Federal election|publisher=news.com.au |location=Australia |date=6 May 2016 |accessdate=4 June 2016 |author=McCabe, Kathy}} Anderson was the second name for the party on the NSW ballot paper. The party fielded 13 [[Australian Senate|senate]] candidates in all six states and 10 candidates in three states for seats in the [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] in the [[Australian federal election, 2016|2016 election]].{{cite web |url=http://www.aec.gov.au/election/candidates.htm |title=Candidates for the 2016 federal election |date=11 June 2016 |access-date=11 June 2016 |publisher=[[Australian Electoral Commission]]}} The party won 0.74% of the primary vote (102,982 votes) in the Senate{{Cite web |url=http://vtr.aec.gov.au/SenateStateFirstPrefsByGroup-20499-NAT.html |title=Australian Electoral Commission Tally Room, retrieved 27 July 2016 |access-date=27 July 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160812105906/http://vtr.aec.gov.au/SenateStateFirstPrefsByGroup-20499-NAT.html |archive-date=12 August 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} and 0.19% of the primary vote (25,337 votes) in the House of Representatives. Their best Senate result was in Western Australia, where they polled 1.11%. Their best result in the House of Representatives was the seat of Farrer, where they polled 6.08%.{{Cite web |url=http://vtr.aec.gov.au/HouseStateFirstPrefsByParty-20499-NAT.htm |title=Australian Electoral Commission Tally Room, retrieved 27 July 2016 |access-date=27 July 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704145222/http://vtr.aec.gov.au/HouseStateFirstPrefsByParty-20499-NAT.htm |archive-date=4 July 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} At the 2017 Bennelong by-election the party polled 0.85%. At the 2018 Batman by-election they polled 1.39%, and in the 2018 Perth by-election they polled 1.18%. At the Wentworth by-election ALA polled 0.20%, third last out of the 16 candidates. ALA president Debbie Robinson stated that the party views by-elections as worthwhile to gain experience. https://vimeo.com/297512990 For the [[Victorian state election, 2018|Victorian election, 2018]] the party has recruited former Australian Conservatives member Avi Yemini as candidate for the Southern Metro region. Yemini is a controversial figure in the Jewish community because of his support for the far right causes. In August 2018, Facebook deleted Avi Yemini's page for hate speech,{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsmaker.com.au/news/373336/facebook-ban-attacks-free-speech-in-australia#.W8Krntl1PIX|title=Facebook Ban 'Attacks Free Speech in Australia'|website=www.newsmaker.com.au|language=en|access-date=2018-10-30}}. Executive Council of Australian Jewry (ECAJ) and Jewish Community Council of Victoria (JCCV) have publicly shunned Yemini.{{Cite news|url=https://www.jewishnews.net.au/yemini-not-represent-us/70749|title='Yemini does not represent us' - The Australian Jewish News|date=2017-11-02|work=The Australian Jewish News|access-date=2018-10-30|language=en-US}} The party polled 0.03% in the lower house and 0.58% in the upper house. In the Southern Metropolitan region, where Avi Yemini was the lead candidate, they polled 0.46%. ==Platform and ideology== The party has released a manifesto listing twenty key policy areas, including "smaller smarter government, integration over separation, real reconciliation: no place for [[apartheid]] in Australia". However, the party has focused most of its efforts on its [[criticism of Islam]]. That includes the party's policy to "stop the Islamisation of Australia",{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/finance/work/leaders/farrightwing-parties-after-your-vote-on-election-day/news-story/dea024a911e4e5bf2d8d6bb6fbd1f0b0|title=Far-right-wing parties after your vote on election day|last1=Murray|first1=Oliver|date=26 April 2016|publisher=news.com.au|accessdate=21 May 2016}} and their efforts to bring noted anti-Islamic speakers such as Geert Wilders.{{Cite news|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-10-21/australian-liberty-alliance-candidates-unveiled-amid-racism-fear/6874336|title=Wilders Senate candidates include ex-Army officer, anti-halal campaigner|date=2015-10-21|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-AU}} The party is focused on stopping Muslim immigration to Australia, and its policy calls for only non-Muslims to be allowed in to the country. The party wants Australia to focus its refugee efforts to assist white South African farmers, even though there is no evidence that they are in need of assistance or that they would qualify as refugees.{{Cite news|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-04-05/fact-check-were-400-white-south-african-farmers-murdered-year/9591724|title=Fact check: Were 400 white South African farmers murdered last year?|date=2018-04-05|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-AU}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.crikey.com.au/2018/04/19/the-white-farmer-plight-myth-exists-nowhere-but-australia/|title=Look at it from South Africa’s point of view ...|date=2018-04-19|work=Crikey|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}} It also calls for restrictions to be placed on Islamic organisations including mosques and Islamic schools in Australia, that are there to service Australia's sizable existing Muslim population.{{cite news|last1=Bourke|first1=Latika|title=Australian Liberty Alliance, the anti-Islam, Donald Trump-style party, claims major growth|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/australian-liberty-alliance-the-antiislam-donald-trumpstyle-party-claims-major-growth-20160406-go08lq.html|accessdate=21 May 2016|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=7 April 2016}} The party has also had to fend off accusations of being climate skeptics, and while they claim they believe that humans have had an effect on the environment, they also raise doubts about the competency of the scientists and that their studies "are not based on scientific fact, but on computerised speculations and consent amongst special interest groups", and about climate change in general with their claim that "extreme natural events were described in Australian poetry a century before the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change created hysteria about rising sea levels."{{Cite web|url=https://www.australianlibertyalliance.org.au/values-and-policies/natural-resources-and-environment.html|title=Natural Resources and Environment|last=proitservice|date=2015-09-29|website=www.australianlibertyalliance.org.au|language=en|access-date=2018-11-08}} One of their stated goals is to prevent any Sharia court system from being established, although they make no comment about similar structures in place for other religions, such as the [[Melbourne Beth Din|Beth Din]] structures for the Jewish community.{{Cite web|url=https://www.australianlibertyalliance.org.au/values-and-policies/australian-law-and-constitution.html|title=Australian Law and Constitution|last=proitservice|date=2015-09-29|website=www.australianlibertyalliance.org.au|language=en|access-date=2018-11-08}} ==See also== *[[Conservatism in Australia]] *[[Q Society of Australia]] {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Best of Enemies | image = Best of Enemies poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = {{Plainlist| * [[Robert Gordon (writer and filmmaker)|Robert Gordon]] * [[Morgan Neville]] }} | producer = {{Plainlist| * Julie Goldman * Clif Phillips * Caryn Capotosto }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * Robert Gordon * Morgan Neville }} | music = Jonathan Kirkscey | cinematography = {{Plainlist| * David Leonard * Mark Schwartzbard * Graham Willoughby }} | editing = {{Plainlist| * Eileen Meyer * Aaron Wickenden }} | production companies = {{Plainlist| * Media Ranch * Tremolo Productions }} | distributor = {{Plainlist| * [[Magnolia Pictures]] * [[Participant Media]] }} | released = {{Film date|2015|01|23|[[2015 Sundance Film Festival|Sundance]]|2015|07|31}} | runtime = 88 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 88:13--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/best-enemies-film | title=''BEST OF ENEMIES'' (15) | publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=July 13, 2015 | accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $750,000<ref name=MemphisFlyer>{{cite web |title=Best of Enemies |url=http://www.memphisflyer.com/memphis/best-of-enemies/Content?oid=4087938 |first=Chris |last=McCoy |date=August 13, 2015 |publisher=Contemporary Media |website=[[Memphis Flyer]] |accessdate=September 2, 2015}}</ref> | gross = $904,119<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=bestofenemies.htm | title=Best of Enemies | work=[[Box Office Mojo]] |publisher=[[IMDb]] | accessdate=August 8, 2015}}</ref> }} '''''Best of Enemies''''' is a 2015 American [[documentary film]] co-directed by [[Robert Gordon (writer and filmmaker)|Robert Gordon]] and [[Morgan Neville]] about the televised debates between intellectuals [[Gore Vidal]] and [[William F. Buckley Jr.]] during the [[United States presidential election, 1968|1968 United States presidential election]]. The film premiered at the [[2015 Sundance Film Festival]]. It was acquired by Magnolia and [[Participant Media]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Ge |first1=Linda |title=Gore Vidal Doc ''Best of Enemies'' Acquired by Magnolia, Participant Media |url=http://www.thewrap.com/gore-vidal-doc-best-of-enemies-acquired-by-magnolia-participant-media/ |accessdate=February 3, 2015 |work=[[TheWrap]] |date=January 28, 2015}}</ref>
The film took five years to make because of struggles to secure funding, get interviews, and uncover archival footage.<ref name="MemphisFlyer" />
== Content == The film examines the ten televised debates between Buckley and Vidal in August 1968 that were moderated by anchorman [[Howard K. Smith]] during [[ABC News]] coverage of the [[Republican National Convention]] in [[Miami Beach]] and the [[Democratic National Convention]] in [[Chicago]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Best of Enemies |url=http://www.sundance.org/projects/best-of-enemies |website=[[Sundance Film Festival]] |publisher=[[The Sundance Institute]] |accessdate=February 7, 2015}}</ref> It especially focuses on a specific incident of on-air insults exchanged by Vidal and Buckley during the Democratic convention, and follows their subsequent thoughts and actions, including articles each wrote for ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' magazine and the years-long litigation that resulted.<ref name="Wills, 2015">{{cite news|last1=Wills|first1=Garry|title=The Buckley Myth|url=http://www.nybooks.com/daily/2015/08/11/william-buckley-myth/|accessdate=June 22, 2016|magazine=[[New York Review of Books]]|date=August 11, 2015}}</ref> It also expands on the impact of these debates on the beginning of modern American punditry.
== Narrative cast == * [[John Lithgow]] (off-camera voice for Vidal)<ref name=v/> * [[Kelsey Grammer]] (off-camera voice for Buckley)<ref name=v>{{cite web |first=Joe |last=Leydon |title=Sundance Film Review: ‘Best of Enemies’|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/review-best-of-enemies-1201413030/ |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=January 23, 2015 |accessdate=August 28, 2015}}</ref> * [[Sam Tanenhaus]], Buckley's authorized biographer<ref name=Scott>{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=A. O.|title=Review: ‘Best of Enemies’ Recalls Gore Vidal and William F. Buckley Jr.’s TV Battles|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/31/movies/review-best-of-enemies-recalls-gore-vidal-and-william-f-buckley-jrs-tv-battles.html|accessdate=August 30, 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=July 30, 2015}}</ref> * [[Dick Cavett]] * [[Christopher Hitchens]] (Hitchens died in December 2011, four years prior to the film’s release.) * [[Brooke Gladstone]] * [[Ginia Bellafante]] * [[James Wolcott]]
== Reception == On December 1, 2015, the film was selected as one of 15 shortlisted for the [[Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.oscars.org/news/15-documentary-features-advance-2015-oscarr-race|title=15 DOCUMENTARY FEATURES ADVANCE IN 2015 OSCAR® RACE|date=December 1, 2015|accessdate=December 16, 2015|work=[[Academy Awards|Oscars.org]]|publisher=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]]|first=Natalie|last=Kojen}}</ref>
It premiered on PBS television on October 3, 2016 during the run-up to the [[2016 United States presidential election]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[PBS]] |work=[[Independent Lens]] |url=https://www.pbs.org/independentlens/films/best-of-enemies/ |title=Best of Enemies |accessdate=August 22, 2018}}</ref>
===Box office=== The film debuted in three theatrical screens on July 31, 2015 as well as video-on-demand. It grossed $50,378 for a 37th-place finish. The second week saw an increase to 19 screens, resulting in a weekend gross of $81,587. Its highest weekend gross came in week three, where it had an expansion to 47 screens, resulting in a weekend gross of $120,986. The maximum number of screens was 69, in its fifth week, but the film went downhill in gross. The film had a 15-week theatrical run before closing on November 12, 2015, with a total of $892,802. The film had a one-week theatrical run in the United Kingdom the week before the film's US release, grossing $11,317 from 6 screens. {{As of|2018|08|22}}, the film has a worldwide total of $904,119.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Best-of-Enemies/United-Kingdom#tab=international | title=Best of Enemies (2015) | work=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]] |publisher=Nahs Information Services | accessdate=November 30, 2015}}</ref>
===Critical response=== <!--Remember to update accessdates when updating the score.--> ''Best of Enemies'' received very positive reviews from critics. [[Review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a 94% rating based on 113 reviews, with an average rating of 7.6/10. The website's critical consensus states: "Smart, fascinating, and funny, ''Best of Enemies'' takes a penetrating—and wildly entertaining—look back at the dawn of pundit politics."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/best_of_enemies_2015/ | title=Best of Enemies (2015) | work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher=[[Fandango Media]] | accessdate=August 22, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a 77 out of 100 rating based on 21 critics, indicating "generally positive reviews".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/best-of-enemies | title=Best of Enemies | work=[[Metacritic]] | publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate=August 8, 2015}}</ref>
A ''Vulture'' article entitled "18 Best Films From Sundance 2015" said of the film, "This might have been both the most entertaining and the saddest film of this year’s Sundance: a riveting gabfest that slowly becomes a lament for the Republic."<ref>{{cite web |first1=Jada |last1=Yuan |first2=Kyle |last2=Buchanan |first3=Bilge |last3=Ebiri |title=The 18 Best Films from Sundance 2015 |url=http://www.vulture.com/2015/02/18-best-films-from-sundance-2015.html |website=Vulture |date=February 18, 2015 |accessdate=February 23, 2015 |publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York Media]]}}</ref> Gordon and Neville appeared on the [[C-SPAN]] program [[Q&A (U.S. talk show)|Q&A]] on July 26, 2015 with host [[Brian Lamb]] to discuss the film.
==Soundtrack== The film was scored by cellist Jonathan Kirkscey.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jonathankirkscey.format.com/about-me |title=Bio & Contact |first=Jonathan |last=Kirkscey |work=Jonathan Kirkscey, Composer |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170322204013/https://jonathankirkscey.format.com/about-me |archivedate=March 22, 2017 |accessdate=August 22, 2018 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The music used in the film's opening sequence is "Portofino" by [[Raymond Scott]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://raymondscott.net/film/filmography/ |title=Filmography |work=RaymondScott.net |publisher=Reckless Night Music |accessdate=August 22, 2018}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:Doutielt3.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Citizens of [[Tournai]] ([[Belgium]]) bury plague victims.]] [[File:Beckov Horne nadvorie 01.jpg|thumb|right|[[Ruins]] of [[Beckov Castle]] in [[Slovakia]]]] The '''crisis of the [[Late Middle Ages]]''' was a series of events in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries that brought centuries of [[Europe]]an prosperity and growth to a halt.{{citation |title=The Crises of the Late Middle Ages: The Case of France|author=James L. Goldsmith |journal=French History |year=1995|volume=9 |issue=4|pages=417–50|doi=10.1093/fh/9.4.417|url=https://academic.oup.com/fh/article-abstract/9/4/417/622520}} Three major crises led to radical changes in all areas of society: demographic collapse, political instabilities and religious upheavals.http://ic.galegroup.com/ic/whic/ReferenceDetailsPage/ReferenceDetailsWindow?displayGroupName=Reference&prodId=WHIC&action=e&windowstate=normal&catId=&documentId=GALE%7CCX3426200028&mode=view&userGroupName=holl83564&jsid=33d6ba6bd380219c2073e86fda0b07d0 A series of [[List of famines|famines]] and plagues, beginning with the [[Great Famine of 1315–17]] and especially the [[Black Death]] of 1347-1351, reduced the population perhaps by half or more as the [[Medieval Warm Period]] came to a close and the first century of the [[Little Ice Age]] began. It took 150 years for the European population to regain the levels of 1300. [[Popular revolts in late-medieval Europe]] and civil wars between nobles within countries such as the [[Wars of the Roses]] were common—with France fighting internally nine times—and there were international conflicts between kings such as [[France]] and [[England]] in the [[Hundred Years' War]]. The unity of the [[Roman Catholic Church]] was shattered by the [[Western Schism]]. The [[Holy Roman Empire]] was also in decline; in the aftermath of the [[Great Interregnum]] (1247–1273), the Empire lost cohesion and politically the separate dynasties of the various German states became more important than their common empire. == Historiography == The expression "Crisis of the Late Middle Ages" is used commonly in western historiography, especially in English and German, and somewhat less among other western European scholarship to refer individually or collectively to different crises besetting Europe in the 14th and 15th centuries. The expression often carries a modifier to refer more specifically to one or another aspect of Late Middle Age crisis, such as the ''Urban''{{thin space}}{{sfn|Phythian-Adams|2002}} Crisis of the Late Middle Ages, or the ''Cultural'',{{sfn|Merrill|1987}} ''Monastic'',{{sfn|Merton|1999|p=188}} ''Religious'', ''Social'', ''Economic'', ''Intellectual'', or ''Agrarian'' crisis of the Late Middle Ages, or a national or regional modifier, e.g. ''Catalan''{{cite book |last1=Ferrer i Mallol |first1=Maria Teresa |last2=Mutgé i Vives|first2=Josefa |title=La corona catalanoaragonesa i el seu entorn mediterrani a la baixa edat mitjana: actes del seminari celebrat a Barcelona, els dies 27 i 28 de novembre de 2003 |trans-title=The Catalan-Aragonese Crown and its Mediterranean Environment in the Late Middle Ages: Acts of the Seminar held in Barcelona, November 27 and 28 2003 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xlP63J3YjDEC&pg=PA1 |series=Anuario de Estudios medievales, Annex 58 |year=2005 |publisher=Editorial CSIC - CSIC Press |location=Barcelona |language=Catalan |isbn=978-84-00-08330-4 |page=1 |oclc=878594930 |type=conference pub. |accessdate=3 November 2018 }} or ''French'' crisis. It is sometimes pluralized (''The Crises...'') but more often is found in the singular as a collective term for the various crises.{{cn|reason=Numerous references exists; section in progress, give it time|date=November 2018}} By 1929, French historian [[Marc Bloch]] was already writing about the effects of the crisis of the Late Middle Ages,{{cite book |author=Institut d'Estudis Catalans |title=Crisis frumentàries, iniciatives privades i polítiques públiques de proveïment a les ciutats catalanes durant la baixa edat mitjana: Coordinació a cura d'Antoni Riera i Melis |trans-title=Crises in grain production, private initiatives and public supply policies to Catalan cities during the Late Middle Ages: Coordination under the care of Antoni Riera i Melis |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4Ow9DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA13 |edition=1 |date=9 September 2013 |publisher=Institut d'Estudis Catalans |location=Barcelona |isbn=978-84-9965-180-4 |page=13 |oclc=870100518 |accessdate=3 November 2018 |quote=2. El debat sobre la crisi de la baixa edat mitjana entre neomalthusians i marxistes en las dècadas centrals del segle XX: L'aparició, el 1949, d'un article d'Edouard Perroy sobre «l'economia encongida»8 va coŀlocar les fams de la premera meitat del segle XIV en el centre del debat sobre l'origen, la cronologia, l'abast, i els efectes de la crisis de la baixa edat mitjana; qüestió que Marc Bloch ja havia esbossat dues dècadas abans.9 Per a un corrent de la historagrafia rural, encapçalat per Michael M. Postan10 i Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie,11 les esmentades fams no són més que la manifestació d'un capgirament de la conjuntura dintre d'un cicle demogràfic i econòmic de llarga durada que s'havia iniciat a mitjan sigle X1; marquen el final dels «bons temps», de l'expansió, i l'inici d'un període d'estancament i de regressió que va cobrir, a bona part d'Europa, el segle XIV i gairebé tot el XV, i al qual s'ha designat com la «crisi de la baixa edat mitjana»12 o la «gran depresió».
  12. Per a la difusió del terme ''crisi'', a mitjan segle XX, entre els historiadors i la seva primera utilització, amb un sentit més social i politic que econòmic, vegeu M. Bourin i F. Menant, 'Avant-propos', a M. Bourin, J. Drendel, i F. Menant (ed.), "Les disettes dans la conjuncture de 1300 en Méditerranée occidentale", Roma, 2011, p.2, nota 6.
The debate about the crisis of the Late Middle Ages between Neomalthusians and Marxists in the middle of the twentieth century: The appearance in 1949 of an article by Edouard Perroy on 'the shrinking economy'8 propelled the famines of the first half of the fourteenth century into the center of the debate on the origin, chronology, scope, and effects of the crisis of the Late Middle Ages; an issue that Marc Bloch had already outlined two decades earlier.9 According to an account of rural historography headed by Michael M. Postan10 and Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie,11 the aforementioned famines are nothing more than the manifestation of a revival of the scenario within a demographic and economic cycle of long duration that had begun in the middle of the tenth century; marking the end of the 'good times' and of the expansion, and the beginning of a period of stagnation and regression that spanned, in much of Europe, the fourteenth century and almost all of the fifteenth, and which has been designated as the 'crisis of the Late Middle Ages'12 or as the 'great depression'.
